comments:
While exploring, I clicked on the CVS tab in preferences, and
seem to have damaged my environment.  I do have CVS, but I wasn't
really planning to introduce eclipse to it yet.   I have a blank
cvs repository in the preferences, but something thinks it is 
enabled.   My first symptom was a complaint about badly formatted
repository tag after modifying a file, but now, after exiting 
eclipse and restarting, I get a blank window with no projects.

Here is some junk for .log which may be diagnostic:

java.version=1.4.2_06
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments:  -data G:\share\projects\eclipse -os win32 -ws win32
-arch x86

!SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 4 2005-03-02 20:59:58.953

this seems to leave me completely dead in the water.  I can't open
my workspace and I can't find anything to turn the **&!* cvs stuff
off!

I can't imagine how an exception in a decorator is bringing down your workbench.
 This is very troubling.

It turns out, it didn't bring down the whole workbench, it just
left things in a state which confused me.  The "welcome" window
was covering everything.  While flailing around I closed it, and
the rest of the environment reappared.

It is still the case that this error occurs every time I start,
and a pop-up complaining about misconfigured CVS appears every time
I save a file.  Very annoying, but at least not fatal.

The real problems (aside from my confusion) are that there seems to be
no way to turn off this unwanted attempt to integrate my exlipse
project with cvs, and (separately) no way to make it work correctly.

We turn off failed decorators but I know there is CVS code that turns them on
again in certain circumstances. We need to see if there is some vicous cycle
being created here.

CVS will only turn on the decorators the first time the CVS UI Plugin starts. 
When this happens, a preference is set to indicate that the decorators should 
never be turned on automatically again. 

From the trace, I don't see how this exception could be doing any harm. 
CVSException is a caught exception and only a runtime exception can be 
propogated to the decoration manager.

I agree that the decorator exception is non the major source
of my complaint.  The problem is that the CVS repository path
is nonfunctional, so all attempts to intereact with the repository
fail.  This results in error pop-ups every time I save a file.

I finally managed to turn off CVS for the project, but it was not
at all an obvious thing.  A first-order fix should be an option
ON THE ERROR POP-UP to turn off CVS for the affected project.

Also, initially, there were NO cvs paths, but eclipse was trying to
use CVS anyway, and of course failing.  I made several attempts to
add working paths, but failed to find the magic combination.  I could
not even DELETE the nonworking paths I had added.  An I haven't been 
able to turn on logging to get a detailed explanation why the CVS paths
are not working.
I think this is a dup of bug 84689.

auto-sharing may explain how CVS got activated in the first place.
It doesn't account for why I can't remove invalid roots, or why
eclipse misbehaves if the root is invalid.
Yup. I'll have a look at these issues when I address bug 84689.

I have fixed the auto-sharing problem. This prevents projects with invalid 
roots from being shared and thus, the other witnessd behavior should not occur.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 84689 ***
